title: Two men charged with murder of athlete stabbed to death on tube
text:
Tashan Daniel was stabbed to death on September 24 (Picture: PA/ SWNS)

Two men have been charged with the murder of an aspiring athlete on a London Underground train.

Tashan Daniel, 20, had been on his way to an Arsenal match when he was stabbed to death at Hillingdon Underground Station on September 24.

Alex Lanning, 21, of Cowdray Road, Uxbridge, and Jonathan Camille, 19, of Fulham Road, Kensington, have both been charged with murder.

Both men have been remanded into custody and will appear at Highbury Corner Magistrates’ Court on October 7, a spokesperson for British Transport Police said.

An 18-year-old woman from West Drayton who had been arrested on suspicion of assisting an offender has since been released under investigation.

He had been on his way to an Arsenal match (Picture: PA)

The talented sprinter dreamed of being a professional athlete (Picture: Facebook/ Tashan Daniel)

The spokesperson thanked the media and the public for helping them with their enquiries.

Tashan, a talented 200-metre sprinter, had been waiting for a train on the platform with a friend when two men provoked a fight with the pair.

One of them then attacked him as he boarded the train and he died in the carriage, despite emergency services rushing to the scene.

His family paid tribute to him during a moving vigil held at the tube station in the days after his death.

Hundreds of mourners sang Amazing Grace together while Tashan’s grieving father, Chandima Daniel, held a photo of his son in the air.

Both men have been remanded into custody (Picture: SWNS)

Grieving father Chandima Daniel said he was ‘proud’ to have been Tashan’s dad (Picture: PA)

During his speech, Mr Daniel said people had told him ‘amazing things’ about Tashan, which made him ‘so proud to be his father’.

He added: ‘This is an amazing turnout, it really is, I don’t know what to say really. It’s just unbelievable.

‘I’m still in a state of shock about what happened, it’s been a roller-coaster of emotions at the moment.’

DCI Sam Blackburn, leading the murder investigation, described Tashan as an ‘upstanding young man’ and said he had only just celebrated his 20th birthday before he died.

He continued: ‘He did not deserve to lose his life during this senseless attack. His family are completely broken by this news and we are doing everything we can to offer them support.’
